awd_titl_txt: I/UCRC Phase I: Robots and Sensors for the Human Well-being
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed I/UCRC for Robots and Sensors for the Human Well-being (RoSeHuB) will focus on complementing a broad variety of off-the-self sensors with intelligent processing software that enables them to extract useful information about the operating environments in medicine and agriculture. RoSeHuB research will make heavy use of commercial cameras that can work in different parts of the electro-magnetic spectrum (i.e., visible, IR, Thermal, etc.), laser or radar sensors, etc. Sensors or sensor systems may exhibit different degrees of mobility. They may be embedded in robots or flying drones or they may be fixed with limited degrees of motion (PTZ cameras). In the areas of algorithms and learning methods the focus and the challenge is on creating methodologies that can balance real-time operation and computational power while providing high level semantic information either for planning, interaction or situational awareness for human operators. With respect to robots, efforts will focus on building systems with advanced mobility, manipulation, human-machine interaction, and coordination skills.

Robots and sensors can lead to more effective precision agriculture techniques that provide more food than current levels while they save water and prevent soil erosion. Similarly, robots play a critical and growing role in modern medicine, from training the next generation of doctors, dentists, and nurses, to comforting and protecting elderly patients in the early stages of dementia. The proposed Center will attract large companies to the pertinent domains and energize innovative startup companies, both through research and through the production of highly trained graduate students with advanced coursework in sensory-based robotic systems and hands-on exposure to multi-disciplinary, integrative systems. The Center will also fund a projects to pursue new pertinent high-risk initiatives, ensuring that technology continues to meet emerging societal needs. RoSeHuB faculty will aggressively recruit women and minority graduate and undergraduate students and host an annual summer camp for middle-schoolers from underrepresented groups.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The NSF Center for Robots and Sensors for the Human Well-Being (RoSe-HuB) was established to bring faculty, students, industry practitioners, and government officials together to explore medium-term solutions to problems faced by industry and that have national importance in the realm of robots and sensors. RoSe-HuB was also formed to broaden participation and create new agile companies and solutions to spur the economy. 

The Purdue site developed several new robotic mechanisms to advance the field of robotics and sensors. The Dextrous Hexrotor is a member of a new class of aerial drones that can hover like a helicopter, but can instantaneously exert forces and torques in any direction. An underwater robotic sediment sampler was also developed to collect more accurate samples of sediment from the bottoms of lakes and rivers to sense and monitor pollution and contamination. The MOTHERSHIP robot was developed with a novel 2-D tread mechanism that helps prevent it from getting stuck. Finally, the Super Baxter manipulation robot for manufacturing and healthcare applications had a human-like face and could learn from humans by observation.

All of these mechanisms, and the complex sensors and software that made them perform, were motivated by and provided solutions to various problems from industry and government. The applications ranged from characterizing residue inside nuclear facilities to measuring physiological processes inside the stomach of a cow. But, more importantly, these projects and collaborations trained a new generation of students to analyze problems, collaborate with disparate stakeholders, and synthesize solutions under unusually difficult conditions. 

The center also made regular outreach to K-12 institutions, created new teaching materials and new classes, and even explored new ways of teaching. Collectively, the center participants encouraged the next generation of engineers and scientists to break barriers and boundaries, while building skills that made them career-ready through team work and critical thinking.


Last Modified: 01/19/2023
Modified by: Richard M Voyles

Images (1 of )
  • Students and professors from Purdue's Polytechnic Institute and College of Engineering display their aerial drones for a site demo at a Dept of Energy nuclear site.
    Collaborative Robotics Lab
    Copyrighted
    Richard M Voyles
    Purdue UAV Team Readies for DoE Trip
  • Purdue's human-like Super Baxter robot learns from watching human performers, while the tiny NUCLEOS is a printable, origami-like robot made from organic materials.
    Collaborative Robotics Lab
    Copyrighted
    Richard M Voyles
    Prof. Richard Voyles displays a variety of robots
  • Tuppy, a smart phone app that combines real-time data from smart containers with observations of user preferences, can suggest menu items based on available pantry items. It can also leverage smart appliance features in the kitchen to teach users how to cook a new meal.
    Collaborative Robotics Lab
    Copyrighted
    Richard M Voyles
    A smart container in the Internet of Kitchen Things with the Tuppy app
